item.title: How to get a job in the third sector – live chat
item.trailText: Want to work in a charity? Get expert advice in our live chat on Wednesday 13 May from 1–3pm BST
item.standFirst: Want to work in a charity? Get expert advice in our live chat on Wednesday 13 May from 1–3pm BST
item.body:
We all want to feel our work is meaningful. Nearly half of the people in the UK say they would like a job that changes the world, and a US survey reveals 51% of people enjoy their job because it offers “the opportunity to make a difference”. So, if you’re socially conscious and want to make a real change in the world, why not work for a charity?

From media communications, to management, fundraising and volunteering — there’s a range of careers in the charity sector. Because the sector is so diverse, it’s worth identifying your skillset and which part of an organisation you would like to work for before you apply.

“Take a moment to think about the experience you’ve gained in your career and how this transfers to a charity role,” says Elaine Smethurst, manager of Working for a Charity. “For example, someone with experience in sales may have the interpersonal skills and database knowledge which could be suited to a role in fundraising.”

Meanwhile, school leavers and graduates should look out for internships and volunteering opportunities to make their applications stand out. “There are various paid and unpaid internship schemes available in charities. Many charity employers also look for volunteering experience – be it organising a school fete, church raffle or volunteering during school or university,” adds Smethurst.

So, if you’re looking for a job in the third sector but need help on where to start, or advice on how to perfect your application – join us on Wednesday 13 May from 1–3pm BST for a live chat with the experts. We’ll be discussing:

  • How to find a job in the charity sector
  • What to include in your CV and cover letter
  • What third sector recruiters are looking for
  • How to make sure your applications are successful

The Q&A takes place in the comments section below this article. Taking part is easier than ever: create a free Guardian account, or log in using your Twitter or Facebook profiles to comment. Alternatively, you can tweet us @GuardianCareers or email your questions to charlotte.seager@theguardian.com who can post them for you.

Panel

Ola Fajobi is global head of human resources at Christian Aid and the managing consultant at Hexion HR Solutions. Previously, Ola headed up the HR function at the British Red Cross and was vice chair of Trustees of People in Aid.

Carla Miller is managing director of Charity People and chair of Carla Miller Coaching & Consulting. She has worked in the charity sector since 1998, has recruited hundreds of fundraisers, and is a qualified career coach.

Henrietta Blyth is people and organisational development director for international charity Tearfund, joining them in 2009 from Christian Aid. Her working life began in journalism and has included voluntary work in Nepal for VSO and consultancy in various African countries for WHO.

Joe Marsh is a consultant on the fundraising team for Prospectus, a specialist recruitment consultancy for the third sector. He has experience recruiting for a variety of charity roles, and now focuses on fundraising appointments across a breadth of organisations.

Andrew Hyland is the recruitment manager for Macmillan Cancer Support with over 12 years recruitment and resourcing experience in the third sector. Over his career he has established recruitment services across a number of public and private business culminating in a CIPD Award in 2010.

Pasca Lane is head of public relations at the disability charity Scope. She started her career in PR working for private sector clients and brands, such as RBS, MasterCard and Unilever, before deciding to move into charity communications.

Glen Manners is business manager for TPP recruitment. He has worked in recruitment across multiple sectors for over 15 years. Glen is now responsible for recruiting a wide range of roles within the not for profit sector.

Sandra Smith is senior consultant at Charisma Charity Recruitment, a specialist recruitment consultancy for the charity sector. For the past 20 years, Smith worked within the corporate sector as recruitment manager for Johnson & Johnson, Sony and Lloyds Banking Group.

Looking for a job? Browse Guardian Jobs or sign up to Guardian Careers for the latest job vacancies and career advice

cards.title: Design a cake and show some love to a footballer on Yaya Touré's 32nd birthday
cards.rawTitle: Design a cake and show some love to a footballer on Yaya Touré's 32nd birthday

item.title: Design a cake and show some love to a footballer on Yaya Touré's 32nd birthday
item.trailText: Premier League footballers aren’t so different from the rest of us. They need to feel loved and appreciated. Manchester City didn’t buy Yaya Touré a birthday cake last year, which shows that anyone can be forgotten. Let’s make up for it this year by designing cakes for Touré and any other players who could be overlooked
item.standFirst:
Premier League footballers aren’t so different from the rest of us. They need to feel loved and appreciated. Manchester City didn’t buy Yaya Touré a birthday cake last year, which shows that anyone can be forgotten. Let’s make up for it this year by designing cakes for Touré and any other players who could be overlooked

  • Share your designs on GuardianWitness or to gallery@theguardian.com
item.body:
The French novelist George Sand summed up the human condition perfectly when she wrote: “There is only one happiness in life, to love and be loved.” Forget money, acclaim, power and prestige; when all of life’s clutter is stripped away, we need two things above all others: to love and to be loved.

Spare a thought then for Yaya Touré, the man who did not receive a cake from his employers on his 31st birthday. Touré’s agent, the ever reasonable Dimitri Seluk, pointed out this grave injustice to the media: “When it was Roberto Carlos’s birthday, the president of Anzhi gave him a Bugatti,” said a concerned Seluk.

“I don’t expect City to present Yaya with a Bugatti. We only asked that they shook his hand and said ‘we congratulate you’. It is the minimum they must do when it is his birthday and the squad is all together. I hear one newspaper has written that City congratulated him from Twitter but this is a joke. It is better they don’t put anything on Twitter if they are not saying anything to him.”

The message is simple: Premier League footballers are not immune from the human condition and, like the rest of us, they prefer cake to mentions on Twitter. So let’s use Touré’s 32nd birthday as an opportunity to show footballers that we have not forgotten them. Design a cake – or a card, or ever a present if you’re feeling very generous – for a footballer and send it to us through GuardianWitness or by emailing gallery@theguardian.com. We will publish the best mock-ups in the next few days.

And, if today is your birthday, have a wonderful time.

cards.rawTitle: Jeremy Clarkson's House of Cars? What should the new Top Gear be called?

item.title: Jeremy Clarkson's House of Cars? What should the new Top Gear be called?
item.trailText: Reports are suggesting the former Top Gear trio are lining up a Netflix show – but what do you think they should call it?
item.standFirst: Reports are suggesting the former Top Gear trio are lining up a Netflix show – but what do you think they should call it?
item.body:
Jeremy Clarkson may look to Kevin Spacey’s Frank Underwood for inspiration for the name of his new, post-Top Gear motoring show, if he ends up going to Netflix.

But instead of House of Cards, the new show would be called … House of Cars, according to the Daily Mirror. Do you see what they did there?

Underwood looks like the kind of guy who would enjoy Top Gear, and Clarkson the sort of bloke who would appreciate the president’s no-nonsense politics (not killing people though, obviously).

Plus, Underwood might have come up with a more robust response when Top Gear’s ill-fated trip to Argentina ended up with the team being chased out of the country. “Doug? Have you ever been to Buenos Aires?”

Netflix, the US video-on-demand service, and ITV remain the two most likely places Clarkson and his pals, James May, Richard Hammond and executive producer Andy Wilman will end up. BBC2, meanwhile, is busy coming up with an entirely new lineup.

If you can’t wait for Clarkson and co to return, here’s a glimpse of what you’re missing as they prepare for their live show (now entirely free of Top Gear branding).

And if you’ve missed heavy things being dropped on cars from a great height - surely BBC2’s reinvention of the show won’t turn its back on this viewer winner - there’s this.

House of Cars is either a brilliant idea or a terrible one, but it’s still preferable to Channel 5 spin-off show, Fifth Gear, which never even got out of second. But can you do better? Readers, it’s over to you.

cards.title: Have you been affected by the second earthquake in Nepal?
cards.rawTitle: Have you been affected by the second earthquake in Nepal?

item.title: Have you been affected by the second earthquake in Nepal?
item.trailText: Nepal has been hit by another strong earthquake, if you’ve been affected we’d like to hear from you. Share your stories and photos via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: Nepal has been hit by another strong earthquake, if you’ve been affected we’d like to hear from you. Share your stories and photos via GuardianWitness
item.body:
Nepal has been hit by another strong earthquake, sending people in the capital Kathmandu rushing out on to the streets just weeks after a devastating quake killed more than 8,000 people and destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes.

The first earthquake caused devastation in the capital city of Kathmandu and triggered an avalanche at Everest, injuring and wounding many people.

Shockwaves from the second quake were felt as far away as the Indian capital, Delhi, and Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh.

As the government and aid groups continue their efforts, we’d like to hear from those who have been affected by the earthquake. Perhaps you live in Nepal, have family members who have been affected or are part of the rescue mission. Are you involved in organising part of the relief effort in the country or from home?

Share your photos, videos and stories and we’ll use your submissions in our reporting.

You can share photos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’ If you’d like to share your photo via Instagram, you can do so by using #GuardianWitness. And you can email us at guardian.witness@guardian.com

item.title: GuardianWitness: How will Australia's 2015 budget affect you?
item.trailText: Tell us how Joe Hockey’s 2015 federal budget will affect you, and we’ll publish some of your responses on Guardian Australia.
item.standFirst: Tell us how Joe Hockey’s 2015 federal budget will affect you, and we’ll publish some of your responses on Guardian Australia.
item.body:
Joe Hockey has announced a raft of changes in his 2015 budget, including generous tax cuts for small business, an overhaul of childcare subsidies, reduced benefits for wealthier pensioners, and savings from some tightening of social security entitlements.

Are you a winner or a loser in the federal government’s announcement? Tell us how the budget will affect you, and we’ll publish some of your responses on Guardian Australia.

See current submissions on the GuardianWitness Budget 2015 assignment here.

To share your views, click on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the new Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’. If you’d prefer, then you can email guardian.witness@theguardian.com

item.title: Art students: put your work on show on the Guardian
item.trailText: Our new section, Students Express, will give students the chance to exhibit work and share ideas with our readers
item.standFirst:
Our new section, Students Express, will give students the chance to exhibit work and share ideas with our readers

  • Take a look at the entries we’ve had so far
item.body:
Here at Guardian Students, we aim to provide a platform for a wide range of student voices. Students use our Blogging Students section to talk about everything from school feminist societies to spiked drinks, university counselling and student drug-dealing.

But we know that not all students are writers by nature. While they have plenty to say, they don’t want to express it through carefully crafted blogs.

Some prefer to paint, sing, draw, film, dance, record, recite, invent, experiment, photograph, yell.

That’s why we’re launching Students Express – a new way for students to send us their work through platforms including GuardianWitness, Instagram, Facebook and Twitter.

Related: The best alternative election posters – in pictures

We’ll be inviting submissions around a variety of themes and plan to compile some of the best ones into galleries and articles on the Guardian site.

Hopefully the topics we come up with will appeal to everyone eventually: art students, science boffins, philosophers, architects, poets, activists, entrepreneurs…

To kick things off, we’re inviting you to share photographs of your artwork for your end of year shows. Whether you’re doing art for A-level or you’re exhibiting in a degree show, we’d love to see what you’ve produced in any of the arty disciplines: sculpture, fashion, painting, illustration, graphics, textiles, animation, model-making, printing and any others we’ve not thought of. Like photography. And film.

Submit your work through GuardianWitness - it’s really straightforward. You can share your art by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’ – and if you add it to the homepage – you can keep up with all our assignments. If you’re on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram you can share your art using #guardianstudents.

Alongside your entry, let us know your name, degree subject and university. Please submit no more than two pieces of artwork each.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others.

Keep up with the latest on Guardian Students: follow us on Twitter at @GdnStudents – and become a member to receive exclusive benefits and our weekly newsletter.
